label: Unauthorised electronic txn - customer negligence
user_story:
Today is 8 February 2026. I mistakenly shared an OTP with a caller and due to this,
fraudulent debits of ₹40,000 happened from my account before I reported the incident to the bank
on 5 January 2026. After I reported, an additional fraudulent debit of ₹5,000 was attempted and
went through before the bank could block the channel. I want the bank to apply the customer
negligence rules where I bear losses before reporting but the bank bears losses after reporting.

api_response.other_info: Thank you for sharing the details of your case. Since you shared the OTP before reporting the fraud, the bank’s rules consider this as customer negligence for the losses that happened before you informed them. Therefore, you are responsible for the ₹40,000 lost before you reported the issue on 5 January. After you reported the fraud, the bank took action, but an additional ₹5,000 was still debited before they could block the channel. According to RBI guidelines, the bank bears the loss for this amount. So, the bank will compensate you ₹5,000, while you bear the ₹40,000 loss. This approach is based on the principle that customers are liable for losses due to their own negligence before reporting, but the bank covers losses occurring after they are informed and have a chance to act. Since no specific bank policy was mentioned, this explanation follows the standard RBI customer negligence rules.
